Hi all (and Kent in particular) -

Kent has said in the original JUnit 4 thread:

> The theme of JUnit 4 is to encourage more developers 
> to write more tests by further simplifying JUnit.

and 

> AFAIK, IDEs look for subclasses of TestCase or classes implementing
a static
> suite() method to identify tests.

imho, that's a problem: IDE's are trying to support JUnit tests
directly.  As another design goal for JUnit 4, I'd recommend making 
it easy for IDE support developers and test flavor developers as
well as for test developers.  That means getting IDE's out of the
business of running tests directly.

In nearly every job I encounter pressure to make tests runnable
under JUnit because of the pervasive IDE and build support 
JUnit enjoys.  Because of the assumptions about test classes and
tests being methods, I've even had to generate classes using 
bytecode toolkits to trick the harness into working.  And using
any variant of test generation entails enforcing code standards 
about what happens in static suite() methods.  

I understand that you're really only concerned with making things
easier for the test developer, but at this point with JUnit being
the de facto standard, making it easier for domain-specific test
flavors to run as JUnit tests would probably increase the amount
of testing that gets done.

You've already asked for a concrete proposal for an API for
dynamically generated tests (fair enough), but I wanted to check
whether you really did want to be in the business of creating
API layers for IDE/test runner support and test-flavor developers.
You already have the layers, but they're not orthogonal because
of shared assumptions about test identifiers, tests as methods, etc.

In process order:

- {Harness}: to gather test specifications, direct and track testing
  (IDE/Ant/... support developer, command-line test deployer)
  Without this, IDE's assume a flavor of test, the JUnit one.

- {TestGatherer}: to select and order tests 
  (test deployer as user, test flavor developer as provider)
  Without this, harness has to make test-flavor-specific assumptions
  about test attributes/metadata and suite composition.

- TestRunner/Test: to create and run each test
  (test developer as user, test flavor developer as provider)
  Where different flavors of tests can be adapted.

- Test/TestCase: for each flavor of test 
  (test developer)
  Here's where the JUnit model (test == Method) is but one.

One harness I've developed is in open source in the AspectJ tree.  It
concretizes some abstractions that might be relevant:

- Test specification: this describes a test (for harness selection,
preflight, and display), and can be used by a factory to create the
test.  Among other things, you can create data- or
specification-driven tests and need only create one test at a time,
which makes it easier to have suites with thousands of generated
tests.  

- Test identifier: In the AspectJ tree, we use the test title as a
test identifier for identifying fixes (failed, now pass) or
regressions (passed, now fail).  This would have to be a first-class
abstraction to avoid knowing too much about test flavors.  (When
generating tests I found it hard to map data-driven identifiers to
method names in generated classes.  And assuming that all tests 
are always passing results in failing-test limbo: ignored
by comment or annotation, rather than being visible and managed.)

- A test run is a composite test composed of sub-runs.  The
distinction between "suite" and "test" is collapsed.  It makes it easy
to write standard test flavors.  For the AspectJ domain, runs are
things like compile, weave, and run, and tests are composed of these
steps.  Put another way, it's tests all the way down (rather than
suite{, suite..}, test.., assert..).  This is also where
decorators can work, since a parent can act as around advice.

- Messages are associated with each run, and are ways to pass signals
around.  The default behavior can be like JUnit asserts (abort on fail
message), but the more useful behavior is for the parent to interpret
expected and actual messages.  This makes it easier to reuse steps
(e.g., database lookup - normal; database lookup (broken pipe)), and
to have endemic logging.  (One critique I have of JUnit is that it
assumes the developer is evaluating a test failure and can re-run the
test (or that the stack trace is sufficient); messages make it easy
for another developer or for build folks to identify things like setup
failures.)

- keywords are simply text associated with a test (cf JavaTest). 
These make it very easy to self-name and anoint tests, and to select
tests based on unions, intersections, etc.  Annotations can be one
source for these. 

- Sandbox is a place for temporary junk, encoding good TDD practice.
(In the AspectJ harness it also provides shared state, so, e.g., the
compiler can set the classpath used when running the class). 
However...)

(This is by no means to say the AspectJ harness is a model for JUnit;
it's feature-driven and not for general use.)

Two other things not in the harness:

- World (in the weaver). For expressly-shared state.  

- a thread's current messages, sandbox, test (i.e., chain of tests),
and world might all be accessible via a threadlocal, so IDE/harnesses
can provide real-time or snapshot information.  Elsewhere I've called
variants of this the test context.

This is  a more ambitious project than upgrading JUnit to simplify 
the test developer's work using annotations and static imports, so
I'm assuming you're not interested in all of it, but might be 
interested in concrete/code proposals for categories/keywords and
factories.  However, I figured now's the time to ask!

Wes
